text:
@KatyElphinstone Nick Walker suggested the term Kinetic Cognitive Style (KCS), which I've come to prefer. I try to say kinetic autistic and then add that kinetic is what's otherwise known as ADHD.
If asked I go into detail, like neurodiversity paradigm and why there is no disorder or deficit.

text:
Some goals and wishes:
1. More music making
2. More reading
3. Less of a content consumer, more of a producer
4. At least as much rowing
5. One job for at least 12 months
6. Less fuckers and delusional people around.
Last but not least: more awareness of my neurodiversity.

@dranilakhan In general people have difficulty accepting difference. The tendency is always to assume people are the same, just perversely behaving differently because they lack character.

This plays out similarly in so many facets of life, not just neurodiversity.

Let's double down:
I hate the term. “Divergent”? Just call me a weirdo and be done with it.

The whole point of the neurodiversity paradigm is that different ways of thinking are equal – “neurodivergent” is directly contrary to that.

One of the many #ActuallyAutistic players of Vortle does something different in the block matching game - playing it on ultra fast speed and instead matching pieces horizontally, the build up vertically.

Neurodiversity of thought.

text:
Me having a neurodivergent mind..

I’m good at hiding my neurodiversity, but that isn’t really me. When I know I’m masking it. 

To fit the “norm” in public, but recently I’ve been letting down the mask & been my quirky neurodivergent self around people.

It’s freeing.

text:
NeuroDivergence, for me, is constantly being told by people who’s brains are unlike mine, that my best is never enough, I need to try harder to be more like them, and learn how to do things their way. 

#NeuroDivergent #NeuroDiversity #MyNeuroDivergentTruth

text:
Allow me to frame this issue with an analogy: Imagine established beliefs in the psych industry as a series of incorrect beliefs built on top of one another like a totem pole.

Every new form of deviance adds a totem, while the neurodiversity movement knocks one down.
tokenized_text: allow me to frame this issue with an analogy : imagine established beliefs in the psych industry as a series of incorrect beliefs built on top of one another like a totem pole . every new form of deviance adds a totem , while the neurodiversity movement knocks one down .

text:
The more traction the neurodiversity movement receives, the more established beliefs and practices in the psych industry tend to fall apart.

It's becoming ever more clear that the psych industry is first and foremost a tool of social conformity, rather than a legitimate science.
tokenized_text: the more traction the neurodiversity movement receives , the more established beliefs and practices in the psych industry tend to fall apart . it ' s becoming ever more clear that the psych industry is first and foremost a tool of social conformity , rather than a legitimate science .

text:
The neurodiversity movement is slowly but surely shifting the paradigm with regards to this issue.

We've come to understand that many forms of neurodivergence aren't actually mentally ill, we're merely different. We simply require social acceptance and accommodations.
tokenized_text: the neurodiversity movement is slowly but surely shifting the paradigm with regards to this issue . we have come to understand that many forms of neurodivergence are not actually mentally ill , we are merely different . we simply require social acceptance and accommodations .

Neurodivergence is relatively new in the DEIA space. It refers to people whose brains function differently than neurotypical brains. Some neurodivergent brain differences include autism, dyslexia, ADHD, dysgraphia, dyspraxia, and Tourettes Syndrome.

text:
What is neurodiversity really?
Neurodivergent brains diverge from ideals of neuro-typicality, but there is no “neurotypical” brain. The neurodiversity model has always been a social model. A meditating monk has a neurodivergent brain.
3/

Neurodiversity is a broad term which includes anyone whose neurology is outside of the statistical majority. Neurodiversity and neurodivergent are terms of inclusion, not exclusion.

text:

text: @AdultingADHD My view is that no one can be an expert in neurodiversity or neurodivergence, ND or NT. Reason being that neurodivergence is dynamic, individual and vast. I believe that people can be specialists ie they have applied knowledge in that area, and/or they can have lived experience.

@yasmin_poole A movement called "neurodiversity" started to gain traction in the 90s… thanks to sociologist Judy Singer.
Rather than taking autism, dyslexia, & other psychological profiles as pathologies that need to be cured, neurodiversity considers them different modes of intelligence.

text:
Ever heard of the term Neurodiversity?

It means that no two brains function in the same manner.

Some common examples of neurodiversity would be people with:
-ADHD
-Autism
-Dyslexia

They add unique and different perspectives to a community and must not be seen as deficits.

text:
Part of my neurodiversity is becoming distressed if people don't believe me. I don't make up stories, especially about serious issues (feminism for example). 

I just don't have the capacity, head-space, or the time, so it bothers me when people question my integrity.

text:
Reminder since #Neurodiversity is trending:

A person in the neurological minority is *neurodivergent* - different from the majority (neurotypical people).

A group of people are *neurodiverse* - a variety of neurotypes, neurotypical AND neurodivergent.

These are not synonyms.

text:
Taking ADHD medications and loving yourself are not antithetical. 

You're not a victim if you take an ADHD medication. You're also not a cheat or a hater of neurodiversity. You can appreciate your creativity, your spontaneity, & your energy and still choose to medicate yourself.

text:
You're allowed to not like how your brain works all the time and still agree that neurodiversity makes sense.

Because it's an observation, not a values statement.

My brain is high-maintenance and tries to kill me if I don't feed it certain compounds; we don't always get along.

text:
Abolition and neurodiversity are complementary concepts; embracing one means embracing the other. 

Those of us who are neurodivergent are already used to living life differently, and (often) on the margins of society.  Abolition offers us a logical alternative.

Because:

🌳 Like trees, neurodiversity is naturally occurring

text:
@EdinburghUni @SMRCResearch @SueReviews @ITAKOM_CONF @eicc So @SueReviews what is #neurodiversity?

Neurodiversity is the fact that all human beings vary in the way our brains work. 

We all:

▶️ take in information in different ways
▶️ process it in different ways
▶️ thus behave in different ways https://t.co/gwBiWas4iM

text:

Big mistake: underestimating the power of neurodiversity at work. Some proven abilities that many neurodivergent people can have:

- Creative problem solving.
- Thinking out of the box.
- Attention to detail.
- Some are able to focus on something for long periods of time.
